docs.title: Welcome to the World of Editing for PvME!
Contributing in its Simplest Form
docs.text:
Making a post in #suggestions. Someone else can see that post and turn it into the edit you want to see added to PvME. For example:

⬥ Pointing out typos/rotation changes in guides

⬥ Writing down strategies for a guide that doesn't exist yet

​

docs.title: The First Steps of Using PvME's Editor Tools
docs.text:
These are the most commonly used tools that are used by editors who want to be a bit more involved in making their edits happen:

⬥ https://pvme.io/guide-editor/:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This is the most important tool editors use. It lets them visualise what the text would look like in discord.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Check out #Guide Editor for a tutorial on how to use it, or a youtube video showing off how easy it is to use

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can load the guide's text content into the guide editor by using the /files ‎command in discord and searching for the guide you want to edit, and clicking on the guide editor link the bot responds with.

⬥ #guide-media-upload-and-request:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A simple command /upload ‎is all it takes to turn your picture into a usable link.

​

docs.title: What to Edit
docs.text:
Unsure of how you can contribute? Here's some ideas:

⬥ Check out #editing-jobs and click the Easy ‎tag at the top of the page as shown here: https://img.pvme.io/images/Fyfjxwn5W3.png

‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• That should filter the channel to only show jobs that are deemed as easy and open to everyone who wants to help out.

⬥ Finding mistakes in guides as you are reading them to learn a new pvm information for yourself

​

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Once you feel comfortable with this caliber of editing, feel free to dive into #intro-to-editing-continued to see some more advanced editing methods and tools.

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
⬥ Some guides require sharing an action bar to go alongside them, but it can be difficult to make in-game if you don't have spare action bars, or if you don't have the required abilities to do so unlocked.

⬥ A couple of tools have been developed that make this process easier.

​

docs.title: Ability Bar Builder
docs.text:
⬥ Try it here: https://pvme.github.io/ability-bar-builder/

⬥ This tool (created by @Unknown user) allows you to quickly create custom revolution bars that you can then take screenshots of, or directly export as .png.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can then send it to #guide-media-upload-and-request to get a image link to use in guides generated.

⬥ To use it, simply click on an ability bar slot and choose an ability to go there.

⬥ You can use the toggles above to change the bar length, toggle the yellow outline on/off, and remove the white number icons.

​

docs.title: Revo Bar Tool
docs.text:
Note: This tool may sometimes be down (towards the end of a month), due to excessive traffic.

​

⬥ Try it here: https://revocalc.fly.dev/

⬥ This tool was created by @Unknown user and allows you to create custom revolution bars, similar to the Ability Bar Builder.

⬥ To use it, drag and drop abilities from the menus above into the bar. To clear a slot on the bar, simply drag out the ability from it.

⬥ You can also simulate using the revolution bar in combat, to compare its long-term sustained DPS with other bars.

​

docs.title: Banner Builder
docs.text:
⬥ A banner summarising key information about a monster should be used atop every guide (or section, if there are multiple like an elite dungeon).

​

⬥ Please note, all banners are stored in the PvME Spreadsheet. Check here before creating one, and if you create one let us know in #editors-chat so it can be added to the sheet.

​

⬥ Head to https://pvme.io/banner-builder/ to start creating your first banner, in your browser, with no design knowledge required!

​

⬥ If you need help, however big or small please ask for help in #editors-chat.

​

⬥ Key information about banners:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• They are sized with the ratio 12w x 5h and a minimum of 300px in height

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• They have the following components:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ A blurry background representing the arena/area the monster lives in

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ The name picture of the monster

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ The monster's size (2x2, 5x5 etc)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Whether poison can be used

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Which weapon the monster is vulnerable to

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Whether familiar damage can be used

​

docs.title: Instructions for manual banner creation
docs.text:
⬥ In some situations (for example, the entire the entire internet falls to robots) you may need to create banners manually

​

⬥ Manual creation will work in any app that supports transparency, for example:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Photoshop

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Gravit.io

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• PowerPoint

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Paint.net

docs.title: Step 1: Create a blurry background and add the boxes
docs.text:
1. Save this template file to your machine and open it in your chosen editor

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Note: If using PowerPoint, unlock aspect ratio to fix pixel dimensions, then type the pixel value into the boxes that say "cm/inch" (e.g. "1440px")

  1. In-game, visit the monster's area and use the Freecam or Orb of oculus to find a nice backdrop for your banner

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Note: A darker environment skybox will usually make the banner look cleaner - experiment!

  1. Screenshot the chosen area, and copy the image into your editor

  2. Re-order your objects so the background is behind/under the template you started with

  3. Crop the background image to the same size as the template

  4. Add a strong blur effect to the background image so you can still see the general vibe of the area but not the details

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Note: If using PowerPoint, right-click image → Picture corrections → Sharpness (-70 to -90%)

​

Good job! You should now have a banner that looks something like below:

​

docs.title: Step 2: Add the monster's name and image
docs.text:
1. Download the Russo One font and install it to your machine

  2. Open and copy this guide layer into your editor

  3. Staying within the red lines, add a text box (start with font size 102px) and enter the boss' name

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Note: If the monster has a long name, reducing the font-size is okay as long as it stays within the red lines

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎b. Note: If using PowerPoint, you will need to eyeball the font-size rather than use pixel font-sizes

  1. Centre the boss' name horizontally in the middle of the white boxes (it should be off-centre to the left)

  2. Get the image of the monster from the Runescape Wiki:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Open the Runescape Wiki, navigate to the monster's page

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎b. Click on the main image - it should maximise the image file

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎c. Right-click download this image

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎d. Import it into your editor (note: this is an important step in some editors, as copying sometimes loses the transparent background)

  1. Move the monster's image to the empty space on the right, and resize as appropriate

  2. You can now safely hide or delete the red guide layer

​

Good job! You should now have a banner that looks something like below:

​

docs.title: Step 3: Add the summary boxes
docs.text:
1. Now comes the fiddly part! Copy in the relevant icons from the below list to the remaining white boxes, ensuring they are centred within their box.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎a. Note: The only non-icon box is the bottom-left, where you will need to use the same font as before to type in the boss' size (start with font size 53px)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎b. Note: You should be able find the boss' size in a table on the Seren godbow Wiki page

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‎c. Note: If using PowerPoint, the align tools are under "Arrange"

​

⬥ Icons (download or copy these into the editor as required):

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Box 3 - Inquisitor Staff

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Box 3 - Hexhunter Bow

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Box 3 - Terrasaur Maul

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Box 3 - Omni guard

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Box 4 - Familiar

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Tick

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Cross

​

Good job! You should now have a finished banner that looks something like below:

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This channel will cover creating icons for our Discord forums, such as the below examples:

​

docs.title: Creating using web app
docs.text:
Link to the tool ⬥ https://pvme.io/forum-icon-builder Finding problems? ⬥ If you have any issues, contact Nick (@neonx222) ⬥ Do not sit struggling alone!

​

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Grab the background image of the boss you're looking for

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. If using https://runescape.wiki then:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Do not right-click the image on the NPC's main page (it is low quality/size)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Instead, click on the image and download the full-size version

​

  1. Once added into the web app, you can move (by dragging) and zoom (by scrolling) the background image

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Try to make the background image in the bottom-right

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎b. Scroll through forum images to get an idea of the style

​

  1. Download your file by clicking the create icon ‎button

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Your icon should be a .png ‎file - if not, use a converter tool online first such as https://cloudconvert.com/webp-to-png

​

  1. Edit the relevant forum inside #bot-test by typing /forum edit ‎and following the instructions

​

  1. Et voila! It's that simple.

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
⬥ Try it for yourself: https://pvme.github.io/guide-editor/

⬥ The PvME Guide Editor, developed by @pleb0025, is a comprehensive editor tool to accelerate guide making for PvME.

⬥ It is the recommended way to write guides, as it makes it easier to check them with the live preview, and prevent issues from occurring with the help of the integrated error checker.

⬥ Additionally, the /files ‎bot command offers the ability to open any current guide directly in the guide editor.

​

docs.title: Editor Layout
docs.text:
⬥ When you open the website you'll see the a layout similar to the following.

⬥ Input Text is where your input text goes.

⬥ Discord Preview is a live preview of what it will look like in discord.

⬥ Error Checker displays any formatting and syntax errors in your text that need to be corrected.

⬥ The Formatting Bar contains tools to help you format your input text.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Covered in detail below.

​

docs.title: Formatting Bar
docs.text: ⬥ The formatting bar at the top contains tools to help format your input text.

docs.title: Text Formatting
docs.text:
⬥ B I U S - Bold, italicize, underline, and strike through.

⬥ H1 - Indents, bolds and underlines paragraph.

⬥ H2 - Bolds and underlines paragraph.

​

docs.title: Lists and Code
docs.text:
⬥ 2 buttons on the left - Reformats selected text as bulleted and numbered lists, respectively.

⬥ 2 buttons on the right - Reformat selected text as inline code and as a code block respectively.

​

docs.title: Misc. Buttons
docs.text:
⬥ <|> - Toggles automatically scrolling of the live preview to the bottom of the preview (mimics guide channels in the discord).

⬥ 👁 - Toggles the live preview on/off, useful for reducing lag when writing very long guides.

⬥ ? - Shows formatting shortcuts and features, and instructions for the editor.

⬥ ⓘ - Some quick links for editors may use, as well as the GitHub issues tab for this website editor for any updates that are in the works.

​

docs.title: Input Text
docs.text:
⬥ Use the left box for input text to write the raw content for your guides.

⬥ There is a live preview on the right, as shown in the layout image above.

⬥ See the question mark ? button on the top right of the web editor for tips to make editing a little quicker.

​

docs.title: Error Checker
docs.text:
⬥ If any style or formatting errors are present in your guide, then they will be listed here.

⬥ The checker is the same as the one used during pull requests on GitHub, so if you see any errors here, fix them before submitting it!

​

docs.title: Video Tutorial
docs.text:
If you prefer to watch a video guide, then see the following tutorial by @trackandxc: https://youtu.be/LQWuufctPLA

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This channel will cover creating and editing:

  1. Emojis used in PvME's guides - https://pvme.io/pvme-settings/#emojis

  2. Icons used in the preset generator - https://pvme.github.io/preset-maker/

​

Requirements Take note of these before you start. Interface scaling ⬥ Ensure both system and RuneScape interface scaling are set to 100%.     • System display scaling can be found under System > Display > Scale for Windows users.     • RuneScape interface scaling can be found under Settings > Graphics > Interface Scaling. ​ Manual emoji creation/Image editing ⬥ Paint.net or better image editing software downloaded. ​ Emoji/icon creation by script ⬥ Python installed. ⬥ Internet connection. ⬥ Paint.net is still highly recommended to manually edit or make icons where the script fails. ​ Raw input picture requirements ⬥ In game interfaces MUST have 0% transparency. ⬥ Must look clear when zoomed in (affected by interface scaling)​

docs.title: Icon formatting
docs.text:
Every icon consists of 4 parts:

  1. The main item - Colour varies, never contains the same shade as the outline and shadow.

  2. The outline - A black border that immediately surrounds the main item (RGB value 0,0,2).

  3. The shadow - A black border that appears bottom-right of the outline where applicable (RGB value 0,0,1).

  4. (Only for stackable items) The number (RGB value 255,255,0).

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Numbers have their own shadows.

​

Image showing different regions selected:

Preset icons are extracted from inventory slots pictures (38x34) and contains all icon parts.

Emojis are extracted from bank pictures and have shadows and numbers removed. They are also cropped to size.

docs.title: RSWiki icons
docs.text:
⬥ All preset icons should be made via the script or manually, and not based on RSWiki icons.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Emojis can be made from RSWiki icons based on conditions below.

​

⬥ The source of the icon determines whether you can use the RSWiki icon as an emoji.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Icons which are prepared by users and accurately reflects how they appear in the game can be used.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If the icon is prepared by a bot. It is most likely a Java icon which do not reflect how the icon looks like in the live game.

docs.title: Icon creation (script)
docs.text:
Currently, the script only works for screen grabs of the inventory section when banking.

​

Setting up

⬥ Download the script here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HKvjtN0J0yIMxPgh0wKTs6sxtIjVTNyI/view?usp=sharing

⬥ Move the script to a desired directory.

⬥ Run the script to set up the folders required.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Let the script to install the Pillow Python package if not installed (required for Python to manipulate images).

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• DO NOT RENAME THE CREATED FOLDERS.

https://youtu.be/PG19o3AzfCc

Making icons/emojis

⬥ Take screen grabs of items from the inventory section of the banking interface (example below) and save it in "Inventory screengrabs" as a .png file.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To make emojis instead of preset icons: add a "_emoji" suffix to the name of the screengrab.

⬥ Navigate back and run "Make icon.py"

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Check that the quantities printed in the terminal are correct.

⬥ Check "Generated emojis" for emojis and "Generated preset icons" for preset icons.

⬥ Use "Archive images.py" to archive all images after they have been added.

⬥ Example video of basic/icon creation:

https://youtu.be/81FjnkxgNoQ

docs.title: Icon creation (manual)
docs.text:
⬥ Take a screen grab of an item from an opaque bank interface (for emojis) or opaque inventory slot (for preset icons)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Your bank background should be uniformly coloured to facilitate background removal.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Items on the Grand Exchange and preset interface have their outlines removed and cannot be used as a source for emojis.

​

Manual icon creation

  1. Open the item you want to make an icon of in Paint.net, crop it as nicely as possible.

  2. Zoom in and crop the inventory slot exactly using rectangle select (this should give you a 38x34 area).

  3. Use the crop to selection option under Image.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Shortcut: Ctrl + Shift + X.

  1. Select the Magic Wand and Rectangle select/Lasso select tools to select and delete regions until the background is completely removed.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Use Shift + Click with the Magic Wand on 0% tolerance on the background to quickly select chunks of regions.

https://youtu.be/ZjdWPbp4YUo

Manual emoji creation

  1. Open the item you want to make an icon of in Paint.net, crop it as nicely as possible.

  2. Select the Magic Wand tool on 0% tolerance and use Shift + Click followed by Delete on the background.

  3. Repeat the previous step for shadow and number pixels.

  4. If removing number pixels, ensure that the number or its shadow do not cover the icon.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Post in #guide-media-upload-and-request if there is no way to get the complete unnumbered icon or visit the Image stacking section below.

  1. Use the Magic Wand again to select the transparent background, press Ctrl + I followed by Ctrl + Shift + X to crop the image to size

https://youtu.be/9oiHOuCO89U

docs.title: Image stacking
docs.text:
If you're trying to emoji-fy a stackable item (check if icon is available on wiki first) and cannot get a whole icon due to the number partially covering it, you can stack multiple incomplete images (made by removing different numbers) to form a complete image.

​

⬥ The most efficient quantities you can use for stacking are not yet known, but generally:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Items without varying icons based on quantity (e.g. teleport tabs), use quantities 1, 7 and 9.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Items with varying icons throughout numbers 1-5 (e.g. Bakriminel bolts), use quantities 11, 44, 77 and 99.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Items with varying icons throughout 1-1000 (e.g. congealed blood), use numbers 1111, 2222, 7777 and 9999.

​

Stacking with the script

  1. Save an image consisting multiple inventories with different quantities of the same item(s) you want stacked.

  2. Run "Make icon.py" to generate the incomplete emojis.

  3. Create respective folders starting with "stack" followed by the item name and sort the incomplete emojis into their respective folders.

  4. Run "Stack.py" to create the stacked icons.

https://youtu.be/MCmgf2WiOeY

Manual stacking

  1. Have images consisting different quantities of the item(s) you want stacked open in different windows.

  2. Carry out removal of background, shadows, and quantities.

  3. Paste the incomplete emojis onto different layers and merge them to get the complete emoji(s).

https://youtu.be/yM61GooZZco

docs.title: Known issues
docs.text:
⬥ Currently, there is not a standardised method for auras and other icons (e.g. buffs, debuffs).

⬥ If your inventory slots (from the banking interface) are not completely uniform, the script will not be able to recognise them as inventory slots.

⬥ The script uses the complete frames of the inventory slot to identify them: https://imgur.com/CCfr7dG, https://imgur.com/ypnZCL3.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If an item has its shadow and/or outline invading the inventory slot, the frame will not be recognised and the item will not be extracted.

Examples:

docs.title: Submitting completed icons
docs.text:
Preset icons - Upload the icon to https://img.pvme.io/ ‎(via #guide-media-upload-and-request), copy the item link, and fill in this template for each item to submit via pasting it to #unknown:

name:
image:
slot:
label:
breakdownNotes:
wikiLink:

Fields explanations:

⬥ name: ‎The item name as displayed on the RSWiki.

⬥ image: ‎The raw https://img.pvme.io/ ‎link.

⬥ slot: ‎Numbers 0 to 13 which decides where the item can be equipped.

INVENTORY = 0

HELM = 1

BODY = 2

LEGS = 3

MH_WEAPON = 4

OH_WEAPON = 5

GLOVES = 6

BOOTS = 7

AURA = 8

AMMO = 9

NECKLACE = 10

RING = 11

CAPE = 12

POCKET = 13

⬥ label: ‎The name: ‎of the item with all lower-case and no spacing OR an acceptable abbreviation.

⬥ breakdownNotes: ‎Default text that appears in item breakdown when an item is picked. This is usually left blank.

⬥ wikiLink: ‎Link to the item on RSWiki.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Make sure the link is valid.

​

Examples:

name: Abyssal scourge
image: https://img.pvme.io/images/Moh9yya.png
slot: 4
label: abyssalscourge
breakdownNotes:
wikiLink: https://runescape.wiki/w/Abyssal_scourge

​

name: Black stone arrows
image: https://img.pvme.io/images/uBbMQoy.png
slot: 9
label: bsa100
breakdownNotes:
wikiLink: https://runescape.wiki/w/Black_stone_arrows

Emojis - Once done creating the emoji(s), use Ctrl + A + Ctrl + C to copy the cropped image (if made manually) or drag and drop saved emojis into #unknown along with the item names.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This channel will cover creating tile-based maps for our guides, such as the below examples:

​

docs.title: Method 1: Creating using web app
docs.text:
Link to the tool ⬥ https://pvme.io/tilemap-maker Finding problems? ⬥ If you have any issues, contact Nick (@neonx222) ⬥ Do not sit struggling alone!

​

docs.title: Method 2: Creating via coding
docs.text:
Link to the tool ⬥ Map Generator on Google Colab Finding problems? ⬥ If you have any issues, contact Chrash (@chrash.) ⬥ Do not sit struggling alone!

​

docs.title: Step 1
docs.text:
1.1 Run the first code section by clicking the first play button

​

docs.title: Step 2
docs.text:
2.1. Scroll down to the second code section and edit the variables between the two lines of #########​

Notes:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Check #unknown first for already created maps and variables sets to save you time

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎b. You can find map chunks by visiting https://mejrs.github.io/

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Turn on the grid layer by hovering over the icon in the bottom-right

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ If you struggle to find a specific area the RS Wiki has a page listing common locations - simply replace the -1 ‎in the mej URL to the corresponding map ID

​

2.2. If unsure about the coloured tile markings, enter a number around where you think for player/cannon etc, then tweak and re-run the code

​

2.3. Choose how many tiles to trim off each side of the image (left,upper,right,bottom)

​

2.4. Select which legend to use from the listed options

​

2.5. Remove the # ‎from any lines you have set (any lines with a # ‎will not be executed)

​

docs.title: Step 3
docs.text:
3.1. Run the main code

3.2. Wait for the code to execute - you can track its progress at the bottom of your browser

​

docs.title: Step 4
docs.text:
4.1. Scroll to the very bottom of the page to view your created map and right click > save ‎when happy, or scroll back up and tweak the variables if it's not right

​

docs.title: The objective: make a player position map for the new Osseous AFK guide.
docs.text:
​

First we find the Rex Matriarch arena (we've had to scroll across Mej's map to find it):

​

Next, we add map gridlines on so we know which map chunks to reference:

​

Now we want to reduce the map to just the Osseous arena (highlighted by the yellow box), which crosses multiple map chunks.

​

First we set the x and y values to be of the top tile (63,153)

mej_x = 63
mej_y = 153

​

Next let's make it so 2 tiles are shown vertically

mej_height = 2
mej_width = 1

​

If we ran the code now, it would give us this:

​

Let's trim off the sides and press the run button to check our map:

left = 1
upper = 43
right = 21
lower = 43

​

​

It's almost there! Let's cut off some of that excess map, put a coloured tile for the player position, and set the legend to show just 'player position':

​

Now let's hit the run button again... we did it!

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The PvME Preset Generator is a website used for creating presets in the standard PVME format. It is the preferred way to display presets in guides.

​

This guide only covers how to use the tool. For full preset formatting, please see #Style Guide or reference any of the other guides in PvME where presets are used.

​

The preset generator can be found here: https://pvme.github.io/preset-maker/

​

If a desired item is not available, request for it in #guide-media-upload-and-request

​

docs.title: Preset Generator Layout
docs.text:
⬥ When you open the preset generator, you'll see the following layout.

⬥ There are 2 buttons shown at the top right.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• IMPORT JSON - Allows you to import preset items and notes via an uploaded JSON file.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• EXPORT JSON - Allows you to export preset items and notes as a downloaded JSON file.

⬥ The GENERATE SHARABLE LINK button produces a link to use in guides which saves all items and notes.

⬥ The SAVE NEW PRESET buttons saves the displayed preset and breakdown which can be loaded when the website is opened again on the same browser.

⬥ The RESET button erases all data in the displayed preset.

⬥ The COPY IMAGE TO CLIPBOARD and COPY BREAKDOWN TO CLIPBOARD buttons copies the preset and breakdown as images respectively.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This facilitates fast uploading of images to #guide-media-upload-and-request, or #bot-test.

​

docs.title: Creating a Preset
docs.text:
⬥ Click on an slot in the preset interface. Use the search bar to find the desired item to assign it with.

⬥ Your last 5 unique entries will be displayed in the Recent Items: section.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• This speeds up filling multiple inventory slots with the same item e.g.

⬥ You can also use the multi-select feature by holding [SHIFT] when selecting the slots, as shown in the video below:

​

docs.title: Adding Preset to Guide
docs.text:
⬥ After you are finished with the preset and breakdown, generate the shareable link (wait for the green confirmation message) and paste the result in the link section of the preset embed.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Click on the link in the guide editor to check that it is working. It may take a bit to load.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The PVMe Spreadsheet is a Google Sheet document that is used to store dynamic information for use in guides. This includes things like prices of items, values of invention components, calculating boss revenue, etc. which can change over time. This guide is a brief overview of the sheet, and how you can use data from it in your guides.

​

The spreadsheet can be found at the following link.

PvME Spreadsheet Check out the PvME Spreadsheet here. You can make a copy for own use, but it will not affect any PvME guides.

Note: Data in guides is only pulled from the master copy of the sheet. To modify existing data, or add new data, use #guide-media-upload-and-request.

​

docs.title: PvME Spreadsheet Layout
docs.text:
⬥ When you open the spreadsheet, you will see the following sheets at the bottom:

⬥ These tabs correspond to different categories of items/etc. within the game for data is present/calculated for use in the guides:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Prices: sheet that contains and periodically fetches/updates GE prices of items.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Bosses: used to calculate earnings for #boss-revenue.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Slayer: used to calculate earnings for #rs3-slayer.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Perks: used to calculate cost of Invention components and perks for #perks.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Unlocks: prices of unlockable items found in #permanent-unlocks.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Miscellaneous: some misc. prices and calculations.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Consumables: prices of consumable items found in #consumables.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Mastery: outdated sheet, kept for historic/reference purposes.

⬥ To access a specific piece of information, only two things are required: the sheet name and named range.

​

docs.title: Using Spreadsheet Data In Guides
docs.text:
⬥ Using data from the spreadsheet in a guide is very straightforward.

⬥ Values from the sheet can be accessed using the following command: data_pvme:<sheet>_<namedrange>, replacing the contents of <sheet> ‎and <namedrange> ‎with the sheet name and named range respectively.

⬥ When posted (by the PvME Bot), the command text will get replaced by the value present in that cell.

​

⬥ For example, the following sentence might be in a guide:

Greater Chain <:gchain:1257440278512537740> is a very powerful ability, but is also quite expensive, costing <:coins:698816156961603654> $data_pvmе:unlock_gchain$.

⬥ When posted by the bot, it will look like the following:

Note: The command syntax can also be found in the Commands dropdown menu in the web guide editor tool.

​

docs.title: Requesting Changes/Additions
docs.text:
⬥ Anyone can make a copy of the sheet for personal use, but only data from the master sheet will be referenced by the bot.

⬥ To request any changes or additions to the sheet, use the #guide-media-upload-and-request channel.

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
⬥ The Rotation Builder is a tool that was developed by @pleb0025 to make writing rotations for guides easier.

⬥ Try it for yourself here: https://pvme.github.io/rotation-builder/

​

docs.title: Rotation Builder Layout
docs.text:
⬥ When you open the website you'll see the a layout similar to the following.

⬥ Input Text is where your input text goes.

⬥ Output is a live output of the emojis from your input text.

⬥ Copy Options allow you to copy the text in a couple different output options.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Copy Discord copies the text as it would be input for a guide in PvME.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Copy Draw.io copies the raw HTML for import into draw.io (a free online tool that helps make flowcharts, diagrams, etc.)

​

docs.title: Input Text
docs.text:
⬥ When typing the name or alias of an emoji from https://pvme.io/pvme-settings/#emojis, the website will automatically display it as an emoji instead of text.

⬥ For example, typing the raw input text gbarge → assault → deci → destroy ‎will yield the following output:

⬥ More examples of how to format input are given on the website.

​

docs.title: Saving Output
docs.text:
⬥ To save it as an image: please screenshot only the output section.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A picture of the rotation looks cleaner and is more easily shared with people than a ton of emoji text IDs.

⬥ To use emojis directly in a guide: use the Copy Discord button and paste the copied text into your guide.

⬥ Copying the data for draw.io: follow the tutorial given at the bottom of the website.

​

docs.title: PvME Style Guide
docs.text:
Consistency makes guides easier to read and maintain. This guide covers formatting, structure, and PvME-specific conventions.

​

docs.title: Sections & Templates
docs.text:
⬥ We have various types of guides, each of which has a unique structure and sections within

⬥ Most templates you will require can be found on the Guide Editor:

​

docs.title: Language & Formatting
docs.text:
⬥ Use UK English (e.g. armour, not armor; defence, not defense)

⬥ Date format: 22nd July 2013

⬥ Do not end lines with blank space (this is referred to as "trailing whitespace")

​

docs.title: Styling & Punctuation
docs.text:
⬥ End full sentences with full stops.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Exceptions: bullet points or if a paragraph ends in an emoji 🚀

​

⬥ Text styles:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• **Bold** ‎– Key items or emphases

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• *Italic* ‎– Inline notes or footnotes

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• __Underline__ ‎– Optional emphasis

​

docs.title: Emojis
docs.text:
⬥ Spacing: Emojis require a space before and after:

❌ Detonate<:deto:123> is a spell.
❌ Spellbook Swap <:SBS:543875425055670275>is a spell.
✅ Spellbook Swap <:SBS:543875425055670275> is a spell.

​

⬥ There are a few exceptions where spaces are not needed:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Letter prefixes (r, s, _)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Punctuation/backslash/backtick prefixes

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Trailing punctuation or underscore

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Inside backticks (embeds)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Invisible characters

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Allowed examples:

r<:emoji:1>  <:emoji:7>.  "…<:emoji:4>…"  <:emoji:7>!  `…<:emoji:11>…`  <emoji:73>\n\u00a0

​

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
⬥ Use sparingly to highlight key info

⬥ Put notes below their related content

⬥ For a single note, show it in-line and italic:

*Note: This is a note.*

⬥ For multiple notes, show as bullets and italic:

*Notes:*
⬥ *This is a note*
⬥ *This is another note*

​

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
⬥ Headings represent sections and sub-sections

​

⬥ Always put a . ‎on the line before any heading (ignore the backslash \ ‎in the below example)

<End of previous section>

\.
## __Section 2__
This is the new section

​

⬥ Use # ‎and underline the title

⬥ Use ## ‎/ ### ‎and underline level 1 and 2 headings

⬥ Level 3 headings:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Discord doesn't allow #### ‎for level 3 headings

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Therefore remove the underline to distinguish

​

# __Title__

## __Section 1__
### __Sub-section 1.1__
### Sub-sub-section 1.1.1

## __Section 2__

## __Section 3__
### __Sub-section 3.1__

​

⬥ Headings should be capitalised following the Oxford style:

✅ Capitalise ⬥ First and last word ⬥ Nouns ⬥ Pronouns ⬥ Verbs ⬥ Adjectives ⬥ Adverbs ⬥ Any word over four letters ❌ Don’t capitalise ⬥ Articles (a, an, the) ⬥ Prepositions (to, on, in, for, with, etc.) ⬥ Conjunctions (and, but, or, nor, etc.)

​

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
⬥ Bulleted lists use different characters depending on the level

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Level 2 bullets should be indented 4 spaces

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Level 3 bullets should be indented 8 spaces

​

1) Numbered Lists follow the same rules with indentation

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a) Level 2 should use letters

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Level 3 should be bullets

​

⬥ Where visually dense, you may add line breaks between list items (like above this bullet)

​

docs.title: Links and Embedded Content
docs.text:
⬥ Only use content from https://runescape.wiki/, https://www.youtube.com/ ‎or https://img.pvme.io/ ‎(via #guide-media-upload-and-request)

⬥ Add angled brackets <> ‎around links to prevent them showing inline

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• For example, [Greater Fury](<https://runescape.wiki/w/Greater_Fury>)​

​

docs.title: Useful Markdown & GitHub Syntax
docs.text:
⬥ ‎`code` ‎ ‎for inline code

⬥ .img:<url> ‎for images

⬥ .tag:sectionName ‎for ToC section targets

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• $linkmsg_sectionName$ ‎for linking to that section

​

docs.title: Filenames
docs.text:
⬥ Filenames should follow these naming patterns:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Basic guides: {bossName}-basic.txt​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Combat Achievements: {bossName}-ca.txt​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Commands: {commandName}.txt​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• DPM Advice: dpm-advice-{style}.txt​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• One-tick guides: {bossName}-one-tick.txt​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Full Boss guides: {bossName}-{difficulty}-{style}.txt​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ {difficulty} ‎is optional; either hm ‎or nm​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ {style} ‎is optional; either ranged, magic, melee, necromancy, hybrid​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Slayer: {monsterName}.txt​

​

⬥ If not listed above, hyphenate the title:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• e.g., interface-guide.txt​

​

⬥ These naming patterns should also apply if the file is inside the boss folder, e.g. /sanctum/sanctum-hm-ranged.txt​

​

docs.title: Presets
docs.text:
⬥ Use the Preset Generator (#Preset Generator)

⬥ Links to presets should be in the following pattern:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• {Combat style} - {Basic/Advanced} {Combat style emoji}​

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ e.g., Necromancy - Basic

⬥ Avoid dyed gear or overpriced items which do not feature in #upgrade-order

⬥ Be consistent with:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Rune pouch colours (#armour-and-weapons)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• EoF emojis (#eof-specs)

​

docs.title: Using Notes in Presets
docs.text:
⬥ Notes relating to specific preset gear/items should be added to the Preset Generator

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Do not add notes to the guide, for example below the Preset image

​

⬥ Add a note for any non-standard gear or niche items

⬥ Add a note on any gear where perks differ from standard ones listed in #perks

​

⬥ For AFK guides, notes may be added to the Mandatory AFK Requirements ‎embed for:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Required ability unlocks (including Talent Tree)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Mandatory gear/items differing from those listed in #AFK Overview

​

docs.title: Rotations
docs.text:
⬥ Use full emoji codes, e.g., <:emoji:ID>​

​

⬥ Use + ‎to combine same-tick actions, e.g., +

​

⬥ Use → ‎to separate ticks and GCDs, e.g., →

​

⬥ Use () ‎for:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Target cycle (tc)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Auto attacks (auto)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Waiting (2t) - ticks are from previous action

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Channel durations (3 hit)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Weapon types (DW) / (2H)

​

⬥ Include non-ability actions, e.g.,

​

⬥ Use s ‎and r ‎to represent stall & release, e.g.:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• s<ability> → r<ability> + <nextability>​

​

⬥ Use the following example pattern for Detonate:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• → (3t) → + + → etc.

​

⬥ Use and properly, e.g.:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Weapon specs: <:sgb> <:spec> ‎

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• EOF specs: <:sgb> <:eofspec> ‎

​

⬥ Show ammo swaps before and after abilities, e.g.:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Single ammo switch: → → etc.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Includes off-style abilities: → etc.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Multiple ammo switch (like "wensporing"): → → etc.

​

⬥ 0-tick abilities should follow this pattern:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• (0tick)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Add a note pointing to the !0tick ‎command

​

docs.title: Table of Contents (ToC)
docs.text:
⬥ Each guide ends with a pinned ToC section

⬥ ToC is always within a Discord embed

⬥ Must be pinned – add .pin:delete ‎under it

⬥ The easiest way to create a ToC is to add a .tag: ‎after all relevant headings, then auto-generate your ToC using the Table of Contents ‎feature on the Guide Editor (see image below)

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If using this method, you should check the words displayed as they may be abbreviated

​

Example:

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This channel contains templates for some of the more commonly used structures in PvME guides. You can use them as they are, or modify them as required.

​

docs.title: Formatting Embeds
docs.text:
This refers to Discord embed messages that are JSON-formatted to produce good looking output. The basic template is shared below, as well as ways to see the output in real-time for faster and easier writing.

​

Embed Visualisers ⬥ Leovoel's Embed Visualiser - preview embed outputs in real time while writing. ⬥ PvME Guide Editor - preview embeds and all PvME markdown syntax in real time while writing.

​

docs.title: Embed Commands
docs.text:
⬥ \n = add a new line.

⬥ \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 = add 4 spaces after a new line.

⬥ \n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0• = add a new line and 4 spaces (to add sub-subpoints).

⬥ \n\u200B = add a blank line at the end of string.

⬥ [text](website link) = add hyperlink (links will only resolve if they are valid and exist).

⬥ [text]($linkmsg_tagword$) = add link to previous discord message in the channel that has been tagged using .tag:tagword ‎(links will only resolve if they are valid and exist).

​

A example embed structure is given below, as a starting point to create your own embeds.

​

..
{
  "embed": {
  "title": "__Embed Template Example__",
  "description": "This is the embed description. Ask for help if you have any questions!",
  "color": 39423,
  "thumbnail": {
    "url": "https://cdn.discordapp.com/embed/avatars/0.png"
  },
  "footer": {
    "icon_url": "https://cdn.discordapp.com/embed/avatars/0.png",
    "text": "Some embed footer text."
  },
  "fields": [
    {
      "name": "__Field 1__",
      "value": "⬥ Field 1 point\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0• Field 1 subpoint\n⬥ Field 1 point"
    },
      {
      "name": "__Field 2__",
      "value": "⬥ Field 2 point\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0• Field 2 subpoint\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0• Field 2 subpoint"
    },
      {
      "name": "__Field 3__",
      "value": "⬥ Field 3 point\n⬥ Field 3 point with embedded hyperlink to [Google Search](https://www.google.com/)."
      }
    ]
  }
}
..embed:json

When rendered, this looks like the following:

​

Embed Template Example This is the embed description. Ask for help if you have any questions! Field 1 ⬥ Field 1 point     • Field 1 subpoint ⬥ Field 1 point Field 2 ⬥ Field 2 point     • Field 2 subpoint     • Field 2 subpoint Field 3 ⬥ Field 3 point ⬥ Field 3 point with embedded hyperlink to Google Search. Some embed footer text.

Note: Not all fields are mandatory, adjust it as required. Other template examples are given below as well.

Note: Links will only resolve if they are valid and exist.

​

docs.title: General Guide Writing Template
docs.text:
The following template covers the basic structure of a guide for reference. Copy this into the Guide Editor tool and use it as a starting point for the guide layout.

​

# Title
..img:https://img.pvme.io/images/gIzPFEV.png
Note: a **Table of Contents** can be found in the pins.

..
## __Intro__
..tag:intro
[Brief overview of the boss]

..
## __Presets__
..tag:presets
{
  "embed": {
    "title": "",
    "color": 39423,
    "image": {
            "url": "[Link to preset image]"
        },
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "__[Preset name] Suggestion__",
        "value": "⬥ [[Preset breakdown]]([Link to preset breakdown])\n\u200B\n\u200B Describe ammo/EoFs",
        "inline": true
      }
    ]
  }
}
..embed:json

..
## __Mechanics__
..tag:mechanics
{
  "embed": {
    "color": 39423,
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "__Mechanic 1__",
        "value": "⬥ [[Description of mechanic]]([Link to gif of mechanic])\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0• [Describe how to handle mechanic]\n\u200B"
      },
      {
        "name": "__Mechanic 2__",
        "value": "⬥ [Description of mechanic]([Link to gif of mechanic])\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0• [Describe how to handle mechanic]"
      }
    ]
  }
}

..embed:json
## __Strategy (Delete if not applicable)__
..tag:strategy
⬥ [Explain the fight and how to generally handle it, break it down into phases if applicable]

..
## __Rotations__ (Delete if not applicable)__
..tag:rotations
⬥ [Phase 1 rotations]
⬥ [Phase 2 rotations]
..
## __Example Kills__
..tag:example

​

docs.title: Table of Contents (Basic)
docs.text:
This is a basic ToC embed structure, typically paired with the previous basic guide layout. All guides must contain a ToC at the end (and in the pinned messages).

​

..
{
  "embed": {
    "title": "__Table of Contents__",
    "color": 39423,
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "__Introduction__",
        "value": "[Link]($linkmsg_intro$)",
        "inline": true
      },
      {
        "name": "__Presets__",
        "value": "[Link]($linkmsg_presets$)",
        "inline": true
      },
      {
        "name": "__Mechanics__",
        "value": "[Link]($linkmsg_mechanics$)",
        "inline": true
      },
      {
        "name": "__Strategy__",
        "value": "[Link]($linkmsg_strategy$)",
        "inline": true
      },
      {
        "name": "__Rotations__",
        "value": "[Link]($linkmsg_rotations$)",
        "inline": true
      },
      {
        "name": "__Example Kills__",
        "value": "[Link]($linkmsg_example$)",
        "inline": true
      }
    ]
  }
}
..embed:json
..pin:delete

Note: Links will only resolve if they are valid and exist.

​

docs.title: Table of Contents (v2)
docs.text:
This is an alternate approach to the Table of Contents embed, and may be useful in cases where the channels are longer, or to make it easier for users to identify relevant sections and links.

​

..
{
  "embed": {
    "title": "__Table of Contents__",
    "color": 39423,
    "fields": [
      {
          "name": "__Group 1__",
        "value": "⬥ [Section 1]($linkmsg_section1$)\n⬥ [Section 2]($linkmsg_section2$)",
            "inline": true
      },
        {
          "name": "__Group 2__",
        "value": "⬥ [Section 1]($linkmsg_basicguide$)\n⬥ [Section 2]($linkmsg_section2$)\n⬥ [Section 3]($linkmsg_section3$)\n⬥ [Section 4]($linkmsg_section4$)",
            "inline": true
      },
      {
        "name": "__Group 3__",
        "value": "⬥ [Section 1]($linkmsg_section1$)\n⬥ [Section 2]($linkmsg_section2$)\n⬥ [Section 3]($linkmsg_section3$)\n⬥ [Section 4]($linkmsg_section4$)",
        "inline": true
      }
    ]
  }
}
..embed:json

When rendered, it looks like the following:

​

Note: Links will only resolve if they are valid and exist.

​

docs.title: Example Kills
docs.text:
An embed format to add example kills to a guide.

​

..
{
  "embed": {
    "title": "__Example Kills__",
    "description": "Some example kills to compare and improve your own kills with.\nSuggested [Video Walkthrough](link_to_walkthrough)",
    "color": 39423,
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "__Magic__ <:Magic:689504724159823906>",
        "value": "⬥ [Kill Description](link_to_kill)"
      },
      {
        "name": "__Melee__ <:melee:1096130867279171706>",
        "value": "⬥ [Kill Description](link_to_kill)"
      },
      {
        "name": "__Ranged__ <:range:580168050121113623>",
        "value": "⬥ [Kill Description](link_to_kill)"
      }
    ]
  }
}
..embed:json

When rendered, it looks like the following:

​

Example Kills Some example kills to compare and improve your own kills with. Suggested Video Walkthrough Magic ⬥ Kill Description Melee ⬥ Kill Description Ranged ⬥ Kill Description

Note: Links will only resolve if they are valid and exist.

​

docs.title: Minimal Embed 1
docs.text:
A regular embed with some optional tags removed, to make it smaller and more compact.

​

..
{
  "embed": {
    "title": "__[embed title]__",
    "description": "[embed description]",
    "color": 39423,
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "__[field name]__",
        "value": "[field contents]"
      }
    ]
  }
}
..embed:json

When rendered, it looks like the following;

​

[embed title] [embed description] [field name] [field contents]

Note: Links will only resolve if they are valid and exist.

​

docs.title: Minimal Embed 2
docs.text:
Another version of a minimal embed, even compact.

​

..
{
  "embed": {
    "title": "__[embed title]__",
    "description": "[embed description]",
    "color": 39423
  }
}
..embed:json

When rendered, it gives the following output:

​

[embed title] [embed description]

Note: Links will only resolve if they are valid and exist.

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
GitHub is a service that lets users maintain a repository of information that is organized, version controlled, and allows for easy contributions from many users. PvME uses GitHub to maintain its guides and information.

​

This guide covers how to use GitHub for contributing to PvME. If you would like to directly skip to the instructions, you can directly navigate to the Tutorial section using the pinned links, and if you would like a quick tutorial, use #Github Quick Guide.

​

Once you have completed this tutorial, you can look at #Github Tips and Troubleshooting for more tips, tricks, and other information.

​

docs.title: How GitHub Works
docs.text:
⬥ GitHub is an Internet hosting service that offers the use of Git repositories, which is how PvME stores its information and guides.

⬥ A repository is a collection of all the files and folders for a project, that is tracked and version controlled.

⬥ Anyone can contribute to the PvME repository.

⬥ The basic contribution process looks like this:

fork PvME repo → make changes → commit changes → make pull request → changes get accepted

⬥ A brief explanation of the steps:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Make a copy of the repository, also known as forking the repository. You now have an up-to-date copy of the PvME files.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Make changes to the files in your repository and commit them to your own repository. You can think of this as "saving" your changes.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• To add your new changes to the PvME repository, make a pull request. This tells PvME that you have changes you want pulled from your files into PvME's files.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Wait for your pull request to be accepted. When this is done, your changes will now be a part of PvME's guides!

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can now re-sync, or delete and re-fork the repository once you want to make more changes.

​

docs.title: Tutorial
docs.text:
The goal of this tutorial is to add your name to the list at the bottom of this guide.

​

docs.title: Step 1: Create a GitHub Account (https://github.com)
docs.text:
⬥ Go to GitHub and use the Sign Up button on the top right of the page.

⬥ Your username and e-mail account will be visible, so ensure you don't include personal information.

⬥ If you have a GitHub account already, it is advised to make a new one for PvME unless you are certain that you haven't doxxed yourself in your commit histories.

For experienced users: If you use the Git CLI, make sure you check your git config [user.name|user.email] ‎configs, as these settings can still dox you, even if you use a new account.

docs.title: Step 2: Fork the PvME Repository (https://github.com/pvme/pvme-guides)
docs.text:
⬥ This creates a personal copy of the repository that you can then edit at your leisure.

⬥ Click the Fork button at the top right of the page, then confirm the creation of the fork.

docs.title: Step 3: Open Your Forked Repository In Your Browser
docs.text:
⬥ You can find it by selecting Your Repositories in the dropdown menu, found by clicking your profile at the top right.

⬥ You will know you are in your forked repository when the top-left of the website looks like this:

For experienced users: You can just clone the repository locally and work from your local machine, whatever you prefer.

docs.title: Step 4: Navigate to the github-tutorial.txt File
docs.text:
⬥ The structure of the PvME repository mimics the server category/channel structure, to navigate through the repository click through folders that share the name of the discord categories, until you find this guide in the GitHub repository.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you are struggling to find a file you can use the search bar at the top.

⬥ The file is located at editor-resources > github-tutorials > github-tutorial.txt.

docs.title: Step 5: Enable Discord Developer Options and Copy Discord ID
docs.text:
⬥ This is required to be able to copy your own Discord ID.

⬥ These settings are accessible at Discord App Settings > Advanced > Developer Console > (turn on).

⬥ After enabling them, you can right-click your name or profile picture to copy your own Discord ID.

docs.title: Step 6: Your First Change and Contribution
docs.text:
⬥ Click the Edit icon at the top right to begin editing the file. It looks like a pencil.

⬥ Paste your Discord ID at the bottom of the file, below the other IDs, in the format <@yourusedidhere>.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Replace the text with your Discord ID.

⬥ Then commit (i.e. save) your changes.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Leave the settings at their default (i.e. "Commit directly to the master ‎branch").

docs.title: Step 7: Create A Pull Request
docs.text:
⬥ Navigate to the Code tab in your personal repository. You will notice that you are now 1 commit ahead - this means you have changes ready to contribute!

⬥ Click the Contribute button and select Pull Request from the drop-down.

⬥ You can add type something like "add my name to github-tutorial" as the commit message, and then create the pull request.

docs.title: Step 8: That's it!
docs.text:
⬥ You're done! If your changes are approved, then your pull request will be merged into PvME.

⬥ The #Github Comprehensive Tutorial channel will get updated, and your name will appear in the channel.

⬥ You can resync or delete your fork after the pull request is accepted. To delete a fork, go to your repo Settings, and scroll down till you find the option to delete. Then follow the confirmation process.

docs.title: Successfully Completed PvME's GitHub Tutorial

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
All of our guides are hosted on GitHub, this is an online service which allows for anyone to make changes to our guides.

​

Before starting there are two important things to know:

⬥ Don't be scared, you wont break anything!

⬥ If you are unsure about anything feel free to ping a member of the editing staff in #editors-chat

​

Note: Make sure that your GitHub account DOES NOT dox you. It is recommended to use a separate account to work etc, as username and email are visible.

Your First Edit Ask questions if you get stumped Bolded and Indented text will change for future edits, but the procedure is the same! For a visual guide, check this video, feel free to follow along to make your first edit. Setting up to Edit ⬥ Get your own copy of repository on github (fork the repository)     • Go here, make an account, then click fork at the top right. ⬥ Find the github-tutorial file (use the search bar at the top) and copy it     • You can also manually navigate the folders (editor-resources/github-tutorials) to find it.     • This may be needed just after you fork the repository. ⬥ Paste the guide into the Guide Editor Making the Changes ⬥ Add your name to the bottom of the 'completed github tutorial' list     • To add your name, type <@id> replacing id with your discord id     • To get your id you need to enter developer mode (settings, advanced, turn on developer mode)     • Click my account, and then using the three dots next to your name, copy user id ⬥ Save the edited guide to a .txt document on your computer ⬥ Head to bot test, type pvme$txtpost, and attach your document ⬥ Check everything works Submitting them to GitHub ⬥ Edit the guide in your Repository with your change     • The edit button is on the top right ⬥ Commit these changes     • The commit button is on the top right ⬥ Head to the homepage of your repository     • Click <>code on the top left ⬥ Click contribute ⬥ Click open pull request ⬥ Make sure the title explains the changes you are making ⬥ Click create pull request ⬥ Done!

From here one of our editing staff will review the pull request, check that everything works, and then merge it into PvME!

​

Note:* The first step in "Setting up to Edit*" only need to be done the first time!

docs.title: Whats Next?
docs.text:
Head into #editing-jobs and have a look at the jobs! We recommend you find an easy one and just give it a go! Make sure to message or ping @Editing Staff in #editors-chat if you need help.

​

Have a look at the tools and references that are available in #unknown. Don't feel the need to read through all of them, just have a look what you think will be useful to you.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This guide will go over an assortment of common issues you may encounter while working with GitHub, as well as a few helpful things you can do to streamline your workflow.

Note: You can always ask any editor or staff for help with GitHub at any time.

​

docs.title: Frequently Used Terminology
docs.text:
⬥ Repository

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A collection of all the files and folders for a single project, that is tracked and version controlled.

⬥ Fork

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A copy of an entire repository. A user can fork a repository to get a personal copy.

⬥ Commit

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Essentially a 'snapshot' of your repository. Think of it like a checkpoint in a video game. Going back to a particular commit shows the entire repository as it was at that point in time. You commit after making your changes, to prepare for a pull request.

⬥ Pull Request

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A request to merge your changes into the main repository, to be accepted by someone with appropriate permissions.

​

docs.title: Failed Checks
docs.text:
⬥ PvME GitHub is set up to automatically check for valid formatting and styling. There are a number of checks, such as:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Trailing whitespace - extra space at the end of a line

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Improper spacing around emojis - emojis must be surrounded by a space on either side

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Message length exceeded (too many characters) - messages cannot exceed 2000 characters

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Invalid embed formatting - creates an invalid embed object.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Invalid commands - any .command: ‎used must be a valid command.

⬥ Checks failing can be avoided by using the web editor (https://pvme.github.io/guide-editor/) to edit your content before adding it to GitHub, as it runs the same style checks that pull requests use. For more information check out, #Guide Editor.

⬥ If your pull request fails due to a check, it will inform you. Click on Details on the check to see why it has failed, and what you can do to fix it.

⬥ Consider the following example:

⬥ The bottom red square tells you what the error is. In this case, the message starting at line 108 and ending at line 139 has too many characters.

⬥ To fix this, click the Edit File option in the following image, to open up editing again to make appropriate changes.

⬥ In this case, we break the single large message into 2 separate messages by hitting Enter, entering a single period . ‎and hitting Enter ‎again. Then commit these changes, and it will update the pull request.

⬥ Your Pull Request should now be error-free once the checks complete again.

​

docs.title: Checks Are Stuck
docs.text:
⬥ Rarely, the style and syntax checks may get stuck, neither succeeding nor failing. In such an event, usually merging a different minor pull request tends to resolve the issue.

⬥ Checks can take some time to complete at times, so wait for at least 20-30 minutes before it is considered an issue.

⬥ In case this occurs, you can contact an editor or staff for assistance.

​

docs.title: Your Branch Is 'X' Commits Behind Master
docs.text:
⬥ When you make a new fork, your fork will look like this:

⬥ However, after some time it may look something like this:

⬥ This is because changes might have happened to the main repository ('X' commits behind) and it is no longer in-sync with your copy. This may cause issues when making a pull request.

⬥ To resolved this, the simplest solution is to delete your fork, and make a new fork of the PvME repository.

⬥ This will give you a fresh, up-to-date copy, and get rid of any lingering issues.

​

For more experienced users: PvME squashes and merges all pull requests. This causes a difference in commit hashes, which is why your branch will be both ahead AND behind in commits after a pull request is accepted. You can clean this up by discarding commits from accepted PRs and syncing your branch to pvme:master. Or by resetting your branch to pvme:master. Or just delete and start over.|

​

docs.title: Multiple Changes & Updating an Existing Pull Request
docs.text:
⬥ It is possible to include changes to multiple files within the same Pull Request, and to amend files you have already modified as part of that Pull Request.

⬥ This can be helpful to reduce the number of PRs being opened, and remove the need of closing a PR and reopening it if a mistake has been made.

​

Note: It is assumed you have already forked the repository.

​

⬥ Consider the scenario: a pull request has been made, with changes to one file, visible in the Files Changed tab.

​

docs.title: Modify an Existing File in the Pull Request
docs.text:
To make an a change to a file that already contains a change, in the same pull request, do the following.

⬥ Navigate to your Pull Request, and go to the Files Changed tab.

⬥ Go to the top right corner of the file you wish to update, click the three dots, then Edit File.

⬥ Make whatever additional changes you like, and then Commit directly to the xxx branch.

⬥ Navigate back to your Pull Request, and the additional change should be included!

​

docs.title: Add a New File to the Pull Request
docs.text:
To edit a different file, and include it in the same pull request, do as follows,

⬥ Navigate to your Pull Request and click on the name of your branch, here:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You are now looking at the main directory of your own branch, where all files will reside.

⬥ Locate the additional file you would like to change, open it, and then click the edit icon.

⬥ Make whatever changes you like, and then Commit directly to the xxx branch.

⬥ Navigate back to your Pull Request, and the additional file should be included!

​

docs.title: File Split View
docs.text:
⬥ When opening a Pull Request, it is good practice to look at your changes and see if any mistakes have been made.

⬥ By default, you will see differences between your changes and the original file in Unified View.

⬥ Sometimes, especially for larger changes, it can be helpful to use Split View instead.

⬥ Navigate to your Pull Request, and go to the Files Changed tab.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• By default, you will see unified changes, as shown below:

⬥ Click the settings icon, select Split, and then Apply and reload.

⬥ Congratulations! From now on, your changes will be shown in Split View.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can reverse the process to go back to a unified view at any time, if you prefer.

​

docs.title: Bulk Replacing
docs.text:
⬥ To bulk replace, either navigate to the Edit menu then select Replace in Files or use the Ctrl+Shift+H keybind to do the same.

⬥ Doing this will open the Search/Replace side menu.

⬥ The search box is where you enter what you want to replace and the replace box is where you enter what you want to replace it with.

⬥ However, most of these results aren't what we're looking for so can be dismissed by hovering over the number to the right and clicking the X to dismiss the whole file or the individual Xs below to dismiss individual matches.

⬥ When you find something you want to replace. you can either right click and click Replace to do it one at a time or you can click the icon to the left of the X to replace all matches in a file.

​

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Welcome to our Feats System channel, the purpose of these challenges is to give you fun objectives to aim for at various encounters, aiming to provide a challenge disregarding any meta whatsoever of farming kills. Happy hunting!

​

All submissions require supporting evidence to be reviewed by staff.

​

docs.title: Submitting for a Role
docs.text:
A submission should be provided as follows, with your in-game name visible:

​

docs.title: Supporting video evidence
docs.text:
​

⬥ Only videos are accepted unless otherwise stated.

Feats System Rules ⬥ All rules used by the PvM Records community apply     • Full list is available here.     • Any new bugs/exploits added to the list that are used prior to being disallowed may result in submission denial. ⬥ Power creep may place submissions on hold. ⬥ Practice mode is allowed by default but disallowed for feats featuring enrage percentages as climbing to that enrage is considered in the placement of the feat. ⬥ Deathtouched darts are not allowed for any feat.

​

docs.title: One Ticks
docs.text:
One Ticks ⬥ Our one tick roles are in collaboration with PvM Records ⬥ They are based off a points system that can be found here ⬥ Note: Point values, and one tick tiers are subject to change.

​

docs.title: PvME Special Roles
docs.text:
"Roles" = Feats only. These do not require the PvM Records roles Available Roles @Party Queue     • Obtain all feats up to and including Adept tier @Feat Enjoyer     • Obtain all feats up to and including Master tier @Featured     • Obtain all feats up to and including Challenger tier @deFeated     • Obtain all feat roles

Please post your submissions in #role-submissions so that they can be reviewed by staff and/or role reviewers. Submissions will be evaluated according to our rules, as follows:

​

docs.title: Initiate Feats
docs.text:
These feats are for those who mastered the basics of a boss and want to start pushing themselves further.

​

@Killer Tick ⬥ **Kill 1 boss in the least ticks possible as recognised by PvM Records @nopenope ⬥ Complete a solo Araxxor kill while executing a top path heal skip @Enchanted Lumberjack ⬥ Defeat Solak using a hatchet as your only main hand weapon**     • This restriction applies to the whole team if doing it in a group @Nature's Wrath ⬥ Defeat Solak with the Wrath curse dealing the final blow     • For this you must die to the instakill attack caused by Solak's mind dying @Medieval Fantasy **⬥ Defeat Vorkath in a hardmode encounter using only melee **     • The Soul Link curse and Blood Reaver Familiar are not permitted     • Restrictions apply to the whole team if doing it in a group @Duo Mirage ⬥ Duo Yakamaru (Mirage phase) @Fight Club ⬥ Complete a hardmode Tzkal-Zuk run after clearing the triple jad wave with only your fists @Skippy McSkipface ⬥ Kill Seiryu in a single cycle, skip the BSD flight phase, and skip the Ambassador spinner phase in solo instances.     • In a row not required

​

docs.title: Adept Feats
docs.text:
A stuntman rises from the ashes. The encounters in this bracket will test your game knowledge and combat improvisation.

​

@Gold Daredevil Achieve Golden Daredevil     • A list of the daredevil feats can be found here     • A screenshot of the achievement in the CA interface can be used in place of a video @True Warden ⬥ Kill Telos at 4000% enrage     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted @Frostbite ⬥ 200ks at Arch-Glacor     • Screenshot is acceptable @nopenopenope ⬥ Complete the Lumbridge strikes back achievement at 300% enrage on the top path of Araxxor     • Must use a Spirit Spider familiar @Solo Vorago NM 6/6 ⬥ Solo Vorago NM on all 6 weeks @Silver Defeater ⬥ Duo Vorago HM on all 6 weeks @Lord of Chaos ⬥ Kill Zamorak at 4000% in a group     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted @Tick Tempest (PvM Records) ⬥ Achieve 14 points from One Tick submissions on the PvM Records leaderboard     • More information can be found here

​

docs.title: Master Feats
docs.text:
The Daredevil rises. Your consistency is unparalleled and your guts immeasurable.

​

@Hypothermic ⬥ Defeat Arch-Glacor at 2500% enrage with no overhead prayers or food     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted demo @Animaster ⬥ 200ks at Telos     • Screenshot is acceptable @Zarosian Prodigy ⬥ Solo AoD @Solo Mirage ⬥ Solo Yakamaru (Mirage phase) @Master of Omens ⬥ Solo Hard Mode Vorago @Tick Tactician (PvM Records) ⬥ Achieve 36 points from One Tick submissions on the PvM Records leaderboard     • More information can be found here @Record Holder (PvM Records) ⬥ Hold a current world record on PvM Records

​

docs.title: Grandmaster Feats
docs.text:
Some would call you crazy, others a madman. We prefer to call you a Feats Fiend.

​

@Last Man Standing ⬥ Defeat 4000% enrage Telos after killing all minions that spawn on phases 4 and 5     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted @Ice Cold ⬥ Kill Arch-Glacor at 4000% enrage     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted @Wrath of Chaos ⬥ Kill Zamorak at 4000% in solo     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted @Golden Defeater ⬥ Solo Hard Mode Vorago on all 6 weeks

​

docs.title: Challenger Feats
docs.text:
These ones are... challenging.

​

@True Animaster ⬥ 200ks at Telos with 4000% start     • No darts allowed     • Must provide VODs + chests + quick chat KC         ⬩ Provide this for any kill between 2nd-10th AND final kill @The Enraged ⬥ Defeat all Enrage bosses at 4000% in 1 inventory without banking     • Reminder: practice mode is not permitted

​

docs.title: Insane Feats
docs.text:
Only the most reckless fighters would attempt such encounters, consistency and extreme skill are in display for the most grueling challenges in this bracket.

​

@Eternal Frostbite ⬥ 200ks at Arch-glacor with 4000% start     • No darts allowed     • Must provide VODs + chests + quick chat KC         ⬩ Provide this for any kill between 2nd-10th AND final kill @Messiah of Mazcab ⬥ Achieve Golden Daredevil in duo     • A list of the daredevil feats can be found here     •This includes puzzle completion; another account may be used to avoid lockout @Tick Perfect (PvM Records) ⬥ Kill all bosses in the least ticks possible as recognised by PvM Records

​

docs.title: Welcome to #suggestions
docs.text:
Here, we welcome any suggestions you want to make on improving the server! See below for steps and tips on making suggestions.

​

docs.title: Categories
docs.text:
⬥ Guide suggestion - Suggestions for guide content or structure (e.g. updated rotations, deleting a redundant section).

​

⬥ Server suggestion - Suggestions for server operations or structure (e.g. improvements to the vod review process, shifting of channels).

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Use #modmail for more sensitive topics.

​

⬥ Command suggestion - Suggestions about changing/introducing commands

​

⬥ Typo Fix - Suggestions highlighting typos to be fixed

​

⬥ Mastery/Feats - Suggestions about changing/introducing feats or masteries.

​

docs.title: Making suggestions
docs.text:
Below outlines the process and suggested steps of making suggestions.

​

  1. Enter the title in the search bar and click "New post".

  1. Enter more details about suggestion (including pictures/vods can be very helpful) and mark your suggestion with relevant tags - $linkmsg_categories$

  1. Include as many details as possible, including but not limited to:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Why the suggestion is good.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎b. Possible limiting factors?

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎c. Alternative ways to implement your idea.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎d. Or even a mock-up of what it will look like once implemented.

  1. If your suggestion thread involved a long discussion, you can provide a (point-form) summary once the discussion concludes to facilitate implementation.

  1. If you see this message, it means an editor is working on implementing your suggestion! You can return to the thread to check on its progress in the future if you find that it's taking too long.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎a. Remember, the fastest way to implement your ideas is always to edit PvME directly! Visit and select Entry Editor

  1. Use this link to leave suggestions anonymously - https://forms.gle/2Q4fPrtsdCZkKEnf8

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The goal of the PvME Mastery System is to allow players to set goals and track progress towards mastering specific boss encounters. Roles that are granted are kept permanently, no matter the meta that they were achieved under.

​

docs.title: Mastery Roles Explained
docs.text:
The PvME mastery system is formed around four distinct ranks. Each rank is meant to be representative of a particular 'snapshot' in a player's journey.

​

⬥ Initiate

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Making the transition from a learner to the start of mastery; the primary goal would be to keep building familiarity with the encounter so as to continue climbing through the ranks.

​

⬥ Adept

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Once fully familiar with a boss at surface level, starts taking larger steps to understand its nuances and explores methods of optimization.

​

⬥ Master

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Displays an extensive understanding of the encounter; utilising efficient tactics with a high degree of proficiency in the relevant style(s).

​

⬥ Grandmaster

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• A true expert achieving peak performance; the most rapid, precise, and difficult tactics are leveraged with near-perfect execution with a focus on high consistency. Grandmasters can take advantage of any form of good luck they encounter to push for a faster time. A player at this skill level would be content to achieve these timers once per hour (applies more literally in some places than others).

​

docs.title: Submitting for a Role
docs.text:
A submission should be provided as follows, with your in-game name visible:

​

⬥ Initiate / Adept

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Screenshots or videos are both accepted unless otherwise stated.

​

⬥ Master / Grandmaster

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Only videos are accepted unless otherwise stated.

​

Please post your submissions in #role-submissions so that they can be reviewed by staff and/or role reviewers. Submissions will be evaluated according to our rules, as follows,

​

Mastery System Rules ⬥ All roles requiring multiple kills will use average times. ⬥ Any timer denoted with ≤ ("sub"), e.g. "≤ 1:00", signifies that anything up until and including that time will be accepted. ⬥ Decimals are ignored entirely for all timers, including averages.     • E.g. 1:00.6 and 1:01.8 would be considered 1:00 and 1:01 = 1:00 average. ⬥ All rules used by the PvM Records community apply     • Full list is available here.     • Any new bugs/exploits added to the list that are used prior to being disallowed may result in submission denial ⬥ Power creep may place submissions on hold. ⬥ Practice mode is not allowed.

docs.text:
In addition to all of the listed mastery objectives, we provide special roles for those who go above and beyond in mastering multiple different encounters.

docs.title: Money-making
docs.text:
Training buyable skills and upgrading your gear can be expensive, but there are money making methods that are effective even as a lower-level player. These are just a few methods you can try out - there are a lot more methods in the game for you to explore.

​

Note: It is assumed that you have no main account / high-level alt. If you can or want to transfer GP from another account (or purchase bonds ), then skip this section.

​

docs.title: Daily Methods
docs.text:
These methods don't take much time and can give enough money to generate some consistent daily revenue, but are limited to being done typically just once a day. Some of these methods or locations may require quests (e.g. Plague's End to unlock Prifddinas to mine crystal sandstone) - you do not have to go out of your way to level your skills (e.g. ), these are simply some of the possible options you have.

​

Combined, these methods are enough to generate a few million GP/day for little time investment.

​

docs.title: Lower level dailies
docs.text:
Vis Wax (requires 50 )

⬥ Use the Vis Wax machine in the Runecrafting Guild to convert runes to Vis Wax - sell for profit.

⬥ Alt1 is a Jagex-allowed third-party application that consists of several quality of life overlays on your screen.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can manually add a plug-in for vis wax combinations.

⬥ Runes used are random each day - use cheaper runes to maximise profit, avoid combination runes.

⬥ You can use vis wax fc ‎FC to find the top and middle runes; if you have 99 you can use the skillcape to find the bottom rune.

​

Shop Runs (requires a little GP )

⬥ Involves buying out shop stock to sell on the GE to other players.

⬥ Check the Wiki for all shop locations.

​

docs.title: Higher level dailies
docs.text:
Potion flask crafting (requires 81 and 89 )

Red sandstone and Crystal Sandstone mining (daily) and crafting.

⬥ You can mine 50 (up to 75 with unlocks) of each type per day to convert into potion flasks (which are tradeable).

​

Player-owned ports (requires one lvl 90 of )

⬥ Very long-term investment, not immediate profit.

⬥ Profit comes once you have reached near the end of player-owned ports and can focus on sending your ships for trade goods like bones to make tradeable scrimshaws to sell.

⬥ See the Player Owned Ports Guide or ask in Discord if you need help with progressing ports.

​

docs.title: Skilling Methods
docs.text: Non-PvM ways to make money. Note that some of these methods (e.g. crafting ) may require high skilling levels, so you can just choose methods that you have the levels for instead.

docs.title: Runecrafting
docs.text:
⬥ Runecrafting high-demand runes can be quite profitable.

⬥ Blood (77 and legacy of Seergaze quest) and necromancy runes (20+ and and Rune Mythos quest) are typically the most profitable runes to craft.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Recommended to have as many boosts as possible while doing this.

docs.title: Croesus  (recommended 80+ in    or )
docs.text:
⬥ The skilling boss Croesus can be very good GP/hr.

⬥ Has both good common drops as well as expensive rare drops (link).

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can use W68 public lobbies or teamforming servers/clans/etc.

docs.title: Big Game Hunter (75+  55+ )
docs.text:
⬥ For example, hunting tier 1 dinosaurs for dragon mattock, or tier 2 dinosaurs to sell their meats to players doing tier 3 dinosaurs can be good profit.

⬥ This requires some practice to do efficiently (link for strategies), but is a nice way to train the skill profitably.

⬥ Use of movement skills and the mobile perk is strongly recommended.

​

docs.title: Miscellaneous methods
docs.text:
The further down the list, the higher the requirements generally become.

​

docs.title: Collecting Zamorak Mjolnirs
docs.text:
⬥ Zamorak mjolnirs can be collected and sold for profit, with few requirements.

⬥ See the Wiki guide for more information.

​

docs.title: Wilderness Flash events
docs.text:
Wilderness Flash events happen every hour, on the hour with 14 different events cycling.

Note: Make sure to toggle PvP off at Vala in Edgeville!

​

⬥ Each event gives a sack of rewards worth on average 225k .

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• ‎ ‎There are 4 special events that give 1-3 sacks and 1 very wild reward sack worth 400k , with a rare chance for a 750M dark onyx core (requires processing to trade).

⬥ The skilling type events are completable at any level and also give a relevant XP lamp.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Combat events will be challenging to complete successfully until lvl70+ as contribution is based on damage dealt.

​

docs.title: Easy Clues
docs.text:
Easy clue scrolls are part of Treasure Trails, in which a player follows a series of clues leading towards a buried treasure. They're a great way to make money early on, averaging around 700k coins per clue. Easy clue scrolls are between 3 to 5 clue steps long.

​

⬥ Gathering

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• You can gather them from either low-level monsters or pickpocketing H.A.M. members.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ 15 Thieving is required.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Levelling up Thieving and Agility to 50 significantly decreases your chance at failing a pickpocketing action.

⬥ Solving

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Easy clue steps (unlike the higher tiers) can always be completed.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Most of the profit from Easy Reward Caskets comes from unique items. that disassemble into Fortunate components.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ Sell the items on the GE directly, usually for 1-1.5m per item.

​

⬥ Clue recommendations

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Emote clues are a type of clue scroll where players perform an emote with specific items equipped. These items can be kept in hidey-holes (27 ), which are storage boxes found at each clue location where they're needed.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Completing clue scrolls means travelling across Gielinor, which is why access to certain teleports can speed up this process a lot.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ The following preset from the Clue Chasers discord is advised if you do decide on solving easy clues frequently.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Alt1 is a Jagex-allowed third-party application that consists of several quality of life overlays on your screen.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎⬩ One of these plug-ins is called the Clue Solver, it checks the clue you have open on your screen and tells you how to solve it.

​

docs.title: Using Invention Machines (requires 72 )
docs.text:
⬥ Auto Alchemiser machines can be used to automatically high-alch items over time.

⬥ Alchemiser mk. II (108 ) is more profitable since it doesn't require fire runes, and processes more items.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• Use the Wiki calculator to help identify items that can be bought on the GE and alched profitably.

⬥ This is passive income over time.

​

docs.title: Welcome to PvME!
docs.text:
PvM Encyclopedia is a collection of resources for RS3 combat. This channel introduces you to how our guide and text channels are organised and presented.

​

docs.title: Getting Involved in PvME
docs.text:
It's important to note that PvME is open source and everyone who wants to contribute is welcome. Regardless of your combat skill level, the editing team would love to have you! Check out and select Entry Editor

​

docs.title: Navigating PvME
docs.text:
Text channels - Interact with other PvME users in these channels.

Social Channels Community interactions, discuss the latest content, ask for help, post your achievements, and more! Social Channels #general #osrs-general #other-social ⬥ Including: Other Games, Fitness, Coding and many more! RS3 Channels #rs3-general #pvm-fails #theorycrafting #achievements Request Channels #pvm-help #pvm-help-forums #vod-reviews #role-submissions #suggestions

​

The rest of the server consists of information channels and guides.

⬥ Use the /guides ‎command to find specific guide channels. Take note to use it in #bot-commands and NOT social channels. Other methods of searching the server include:

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• The Ctrl + K Discord function.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• #directory which lists all channels currently maintained in PvME.

‎ ‎ ‎ ‎• If you've exhausted all the other options, ask in #pvm-help for help.

​

docs.title: PVM Help
docs.text:
Link: #pvm-help / #pvm-help-forums

​
